title: Long Distance Running and Health
content: Long distance running can have significant impacts on health, including transforming the body and improving cardiovascular fitness. However, it can also lead to injuries if not done properly. Training programs, such as Run Free Training, can help runners of all levels improve their performance and avoid injury. Nutrition also plays a crucial role in a runner's health and performance.

title: Effects of Altitude on Health and Fitness
content: Living and training at high altitudes can have significant effects on cardiovascular health and fitness. It can improve aerobic efficiency and enhance the body's ability to perform at high intensities. However, it's important to adjust training routines when at high altitudes to avoid overexertion and injury. Spending time at high altitudes can also lead to improvements in fitness levels when returning to sea level.

title: Strength Training and Health
content: Strength training can lead to significant improvements in health and fitness, including increased muscle mass and strength. However, it's important to vary training routines to continue seeing growth and avoid plateaus. Techniques such as progressive overload and blood flow restriction can help enhance the effectiveness of strength training. However, care must be taken to avoid injuries, particularly when performing exercises that the body is not accustomed to.

title: Recovery from Injury
content: Recovering from injuries is a crucial aspect of maintaining health and fitness. Techniques such as blood flow restriction training can aid in recovery. However, it's important to avoid activities that could lead to injury, particularly when preparing for major events such as the Olympics.

title: Mental Health and Competitive Sports
content: Competing in sports such as long distance running can have significant impacts on mental health. It requires a positive mindset and the ability to bounce back from setbacks. Encouraging others can also help improve one's own mental state during competition. However, it's important to manage expectations and be prepared for any situation to avoid mental stress and disappointment.

title: Importance of Speed, Power, and Strength for Runners
content: For a marathon pace 4:42 to 4:48 [12.5-12.8 mph], these are such insanely fast speeds that the likelihood that a person could run that speed for half a mile, is virtually zero. Distance runners need speed. This is important, distance runners are not slow world class marathoners. He wants the guy he’s coaching right now to run 400 meters in 49 seconds. That’s the kind of speed that is needed to win. One doesn’t have to have that speed while they’re doing marathon training, but they need to have had that speed before that, as a kid growing up.

title: Strength Training for Power and Speed
content: Power is so important for all distance runners. A marathon runner has to have that speed. Maybe it’s not as important for super ultra stuff. He knows Meb was doing deadlifts as he was preparing for 2014. He talked to a guy who had overseen part of his strength training program; one of the things he was really fixated on was his strength to weight ratio as measured by a deadlift. A hex bar deadlift with a high concentric and a dropped eccentric.

title: How Strength Factors into Running Form and Speed
content: When someone runs, they have to hit the ground with a toe. Let’s assume the toe is striking the ground, not the heel. The harder one hits the ground, the harder the ground hits them. The harder the ground hits, the higher one goes. The higher one goes, the further their stride. They calculated that for Meb to run the pace he wanted to run in Boston that year, he needed to add 4 inches to his stride.

title: Analyzing Running Stride to Improve Speed
content: Peter asks if he has used a device called a G flight. It’s these two little red boxes that shine a laser beam between them and they measure how high someone can jump and their ground contact time. This has become part of Peter’s training. It shins a little laser across the floor; one lays the device on the floor and stands between them static then jumps up and down. It will tell, with incredible precision how high one has jumped because it measures how long they were off the groups.

title: The Mental Aspect of Training and the Power of Reframing Negative Thoughts
content: Running is very nonlinear. The pain he was feeling at 5 miles; this is a quarter of the distance of 13 miles in terms of effort. Now when he trains athletes he tells them “you got to have a whole bunch of different arrows essentially that you can pull out and use. Cause sometimes you use one thing, it doesn’t work; you’ve got to go to something else.” He has all these different tactics and managing pain and discomfort, but honestly, one of the biggest ones that is most helpful is simply turning the mind off.

title: The Importance of Being in the Present Moment
content: He gets in trouble when he starts thinking too far down the road. It’s easy to get overwhelmed with the scope of the challenge, especially when trying to do something one has never done before and being in the worst discomfort.

title: The Importance of Mental Fortitude in Physical Challenges
content: If one can bring themselves back to the present moment of what they’re doing right now, there is always enough to get them through the moment. This is why it's important to only try to do what is in front of you, run the mile you are in and bring yourself to the present moment. This requires an extra level of mental fortitude to stay competitive in the race. It all comes back to getting excited, right? If you’re going to perform well, you’ve got to be excited about how you’re doing… find something to get excited about in that moment.

title: The Power of Accepting and Reframing Negative Thoughts
content: Reframing things in one’s mind is one of the most helpful things one can do. Accepting and reframing negative thoughts can help one embrace a really beautiful experience. This is something that can be life changing. It's important to change how you are thinking about the whole situation, especially when you’re in a race and it’s not unfolding how you want it to unfold.

title: The Importance of Consistency in Training
content: The most important part of training is consistency. It blows my mind what my body’s capable of doing; and my athletes are capable of doing when you’re just consistent. A big part about being successful in running fitness is like, just make the bar low, make it easy to be consistent.

title: The Importance of Fueling and Diet in Physical Challenges
content: Fueling is important when doing any kind of ultra stuff. If one takes in enough calories and stays hydrated, they can get through anything. One can train their gut to take in stuff. Problems arise when one eats new stuff they’re not used to. It's important to never try something new leading up to a race; always try it in training.

title: Boosting Performance with Tylenol and Keeping Core Temperature Down
content: Tylenol can give a 1-2% boost in performance. It’s not clear if this comes through temperature reduction or pain reduction. Keeping the core temperature cool can boost performance.

title: Effects of Body Temperature on Performance
content: He would start at 98 or 99o F and would come out of the water at 93, 94. There would be a performance detriment with the core temperature went too low. Too much or too little temp is pretty bad. The best way to lower cort temp is through one’s face, the upper face where there is no hair. The next best is through the hands and bottoms of the feet. They developed this glove to dump heat. It’s not icy cold, just cool. One doesn’t want it too cold. It dumps heat and brings the core temperature down.

title: Use of Cooling Devices in Training
content: Ryan has been playing a little with holding a cold pack in his hands between lifts or putting his hands in cool water to dump his temp. Peter has tried a cooling helmet. The helmet had gel pack inserts that could be frozen in the freezer. When he would ride his trainer wearing this cooling helmet, it definitely made a difference. Many people invest in a cooling vest; it’s a vest that runs ice water around one’s torso. Finally Peter got one and it was a game changer.

title: Incorporating Cooling into Running
content: Peter can see how cooling could be used in strength training but wonders how it could be incorporated into a marathon. Ryan thinks cooling would be useful before a race when the athlete is warming-up, doing drills and strides. This would help get the core temperature back down by dumping some heat. In interval training, cooling could be done between sets. He’ll use a bucket of cold water at the track for the athletes to put their hands in inbetween sets. It feels like it makes a big difference.

title: Mindset and Performance
content: In his senior year, his identity was all wrapped up in his performances. This is why he struggled with depression. He would look in the mirror in the morning, he was struggling with running, he was hurt. He was frustrated with how things were going; he wasn’t getting better. He just saw himself as a failure and it was very difficult to have that happen every single morning, get up, look in the mirror failure. Focusing on his faith helped him change his mindset. Faith had always been a huge part of his life; when he went back home he started to realize that he needed to see himself as God sees him.

title: Transition to Marathon Running
content: Ryan never thought he would run a marathon. He grew up loving the movie Prefontaine and that scene where the lead character says, “no one’s going to tell me I’m not fast enough”. But Ryan wasn’t fast enough; he wanted to be a miler. He ran 50 for 400 in high school. But only having that kind of speed limited his upper end potentia. In the 5,000 meters guys are closing in 52. So if his top end speed is 50, he’s going to have a hard time closing in 52. His best 5K was 13:16. To put this in perspective, the American record for the 5K is around 12:50. At the time, his 5K was one of the faster times.

title: Marathon Running and Health
content: His best half marathon was completed in 59:43, breaking the American record by over a minute. He ran the first mile in 5:35 and maintained a steady pace throughout. He experienced a minor health issue around mile 9 where his stomach felt a bit unsettled, but this passed quickly. He did not take in any fluids during the half marathon as the weather was cool. He was in good physical shape at the time of the marathon. He emphasizes the importance of speed training, having spent 10 years working on his 5K speed before moving onto marathon training. He believes that maintaining 5K fitness makes longer runs feel easier.

title: Health Challenges for Retired Athletes
content: Retirement can be a difficult process for athletes, often leading to a sense of identity loss. Transitioning out of sport requires finding new ways to express oneself and stay true to one's identity. Physical challenges and growth are still important, and finding new ways to achieve these can help with the transition. It's also important to remember that athletic performance is not meant to last forever, and it's okay for it to come to an end.

title: Marathon Training Regimen and Health
content: A typical week of training would involve intervals on Tuesday, focusing on 5K-specific speed. The intensity of these intervals was not maxed out, allowing for quicker recovery. After a hard run, it's beneficial to do weights, ideally in the afternoon. Sleep is crucial for recovery, with professional runners often sleeping 9-10 hours a night and taking naps during the day. Maintaining optimal body weight for competition is also important, with a gradual reduction in body weight leading up to a competition.

title: Health Implications of Intense Training
content: Intense training can have negative health implications. For example, testosterone levels can drop significantly, which was the case for him, with levels dropping to clinically low levels during periods of intense training. However, these levels would rise again after a two-week break. Body weight can also drop significantly during training, which can negatively impact performance if it drops too low. It's important to gain weight in a healthy way during periods of rest.

title: Effects of Body Weight on Health
content: When he was trying to get down to weights that were pretty far from his normal, it was unhealthy and that’s why he couldn’t stay in the 137’s, 140s for very long. He would get rundown, his motivation would go down, his training would go to crap.

title: Importance of Training Volume and Intensity
content: Training volume, importance of mixing up the intensity level, and zone 2 and zone 5 for longevity. To really see how good you can get, one needs to have super hard days and easy, super chill days. Having that variance between pacing is super important. This allows one to stress the body, then rest the body (keep repeating the cycle). The body will adapt.

title: Effects of Caffeine on Training
content: Ryan notes that caffeine helps; he recommends only having caffeine before hard training days. Then on the easy day it feels like death because you’re tired from the workout but also because of the lack of caffeine. This forces you to take it really slow.

title: Impactful Adjustments to Training
content: One big adjustment was to space things out. He ran intervals on Tuesday and then a long threshold on Friday, with 2 easy days before that. The threshold run is a constant pace, slightly higher than race pace but a shorter distance.

title: Learning from Failure and Performance at the Olympics
content: Going into the 2012 Olympics in London after Boston. Peter remarks, “the most amazing part of your journey is not the successes. It’s the way in which you’ve been able to kind of carry yourself through the failures.” There is this parallel between ’07 and ’08; and then again in ’11 and ’12. In how he was feeling going into London. The expectations early in that season were very high.

title: Importance of Weight Management in Training
content: Leading up to the buildup for Beijing, he did the same thing; and it made his training run flat. If he would’ve told a coach what he was going to do, the coach would say, “That’s a really bad idea. Let’s just stick with what we know works for you in this situation. And that’s putting on 10 pounds.” So instead of putting on 10 pounds, he did a 1-week fast. His body wasn’t in a good state. Mentally and spiritually, he was in the best spot he’d ever been. But his body wasn’t ready to go at all; it needed a break after that.

title: Effects of Depleted Body State on Training
content: So instead of his weight going from 137 to 150 during that 2-week period, it went from 137 to 130 flat. He started the training in a really depleted state. He began his training and was running pretty well initially, but it went downhill from there. It became a miracle that he even made it to the starting line, considering how poorly his training was going. If he’s not taking in enough calories; it doesn’t matter how he’s training, it’s not going to work. That’s how it was for him in that buildup, his body was depleted. He didn’t have enough calories on board.

title: Impact of Injury on Performance
content: But early in the race his right hamstring started hurting, and that’s ultimately what led him to drop out as I was in the middle of that race. He was already starting to limp a little seven miles into the race. He had to be smart, because this is his livelihood, and he’s looking out for the long term. But at the same time, he also wants to be good to his body, and he’s not been good to his body a lot.

title: Role of Nutrition in Injury Prevention
content: Looking back on it, a big piece of it was nutrition. He got to a better point mentally where he didn’t have to use food binging as a mechanism after bad races. But he still needed to put on weight. Looking back, this is a big part of why he had so many struggles from 2012 through his retirement in 2016. He still needed to get his body in a good spot and wasn’t doing that because he didn’t need to do it from an emotional, mental standpoint. Physically, this was killing him.

title: Importance of Rest Periods in Training
content: If he could go back, he would do something his mom always wanted for him. He would take 3 months completely off and not run at all. At the time he thought this suggestion was crazy. But it would have been super helpful, just to get away from it and get his body back into a good spot.

title: Benefits of Weight Lifting and Cardio for Overall Health
content: Now he feels better in his current lifestyle, focused on lifting and doing minimal on the endurance end. His testosterone is better; it was recently tested at 1000. This is a result of his lifestyle shift: lifting heavy, eating more calories, having his body in a better state, sleeping a tone. His body has been restored. Lifting has helped him give back to his body. Lifting is something he’s not genetically gifted at, but he loves the challenge.

title: Impact of Hormonal Health on Mental Health and Energy Levels
content: Ryan notes that hormonal health really affects mental health, motivation, and energy levels. For him, he can run every single day and be healthy. But as you get older, you need to do something to offset how depleting of the body this can be. For him, this is where weightlifting comes in.

title: Performance Enhancing Drugs in Marathon Runners
content: Peter asks about drug use in running; for competitive cycling drug use is the norm. Why is it that marathon runners, who would benefit from tons of performance enhancing drugs (PEDs), traditionally haven’t used them? Ryan thinks it’s the culture. He knew guys who 100% were not on drugs and were winning races.

title: Traits of the Greatest Marathon Runners
content: Ryan notes it’s a perfect storm or highly motivated individuals who are highly genetically gifted. There are some theories about a small pelvis being helpful for distance running. When he walks behind his kids sometimes on hikes he notices how narrow their shoulders are and how small their bone structure is. It’s crazy; they’re just so small.

title: Impact of Shoes on Marathon Performance
content: With the new technology people are running two minutes faster over the marathon with these shoes on. But I think it’s affected the psyche a ton. Now people are trying insane stuff, like a sub-2 hour marathon. That would have never happened without these shoes.

title: Training for Marathon Challenge
content: He started training because if he was going to do this, he wanted to enjoy it. He didn’t enjoy the training. He started getting a lot of the same fatigue issues that came with professional running. So he decided to stop training and enjoy his life for the 9 months leading up to this. He ran 3 days a week, between 5-8 miles. 8 miles was his longest run leading up to this challenge where he was going to run 183 miles in 1 week.

title: Nutrition During Marathon
content: His idea was to take in 50 g of protein every 7 miles or so because he didn’t want to lose his gains. Usually he takes in simple sugar. With this new nutrition by mile 23 he is completely out of it; he needed sugar stat. His protein bar hardly has any carbs in it. At a support tent (which was unmanned) they had laid out dried fruit and candy. He crawls in there and grabs as much candy as he can. He started feeling better immediately.

title: Physical Challenges During Marathon
content: The problem after Morocco was he developed a bit of a limp; his hip was bothering him. But in Dubai his hip was on fire and he knew something was really wrong. He ended up walking the back half of that marathon. When they landed in Sydney he tries to stand and put weight on the leg where the hip was bothering him and the pain took his breath away. The pain was super sharp. He knew he was in trouble. He had a hard time putting any weight on it at all.

title: Importance of Recovery and Self-Care
content: He was also sick of all the tiny things you do as a pro runner. Mobility stretching, etc. He wasn’t doing any of this. He didn’t wear compression socks the entire week. When he got to Sydney his ankles looked like elephant ankles, they were so swollen. It was actually painful.

title: Reflections on Running and Coaching
content: That whole sentiment just hit him super hard; saying goodbye to the sport he loves. But then, it’s been such a beautiful transition though of realizing that that whole season was about seeing how good he could get. Since then he’s realized it wasn’t just for him. Everything he’s learned in that season was meant to be passed down. It was meant to be shared and meant to help other people. This launched him into the season coaching. He’s far more concerned with his athletes happiness than with how fast they are.
